column6: Seeing them enjoy school, be excited about learning something new
column7: My prep takes place either in the evening, early morning or during prep time in the day. I spend most of the day in the classroom providing instruction, support and monitoring/encouraging engagement.
column9: Teams, YouTube, nearpod, Evulpo, kahoot, digital whiteboard, PowerPoint, websites, Microsoft forms, one note Chat gpt to aid with planning and assessment.
column11: To generate assessment rubrics based on Lehrplan 21 in English - it was able to process very large pieces of information quickly and produce a template and prompt that I could adapt and reuse. What didnâ€™t work well was it took some trial and error to word my prompts in a way that produced what I desired - formatting and language. However, the platform ask questions and suggestions that helped a lot. What would have taken weeks of work at the start of my career took a few hours.
column12: I have just moved from 11+ years teaching in Secondary to teaching in Primary, as such I am sometimes accidentally pitching my explanations and materials too high for the ability of the students. What I do is revisit the material again but break it down into â€˜bite sizeâ€™ chunks. I also make sure I have a range of activities from grade 3-grade 8 so I can provide a child with what is appropriate. If they are struggling I ask if they want to try something easier or keep with the challenge - a lot of them keep up with the challenge and manage the work with my support. I now plan my lessons so I cover only one key topic and then let them consolidate with differentiated work

column3:
ChatGPT:

I currently teach a 4th grade class and am responsible for all subjects except French. I am the homeroom teacher.
column5: What I enjoy most about teaching is accompanying children on their learning journey and being someone who always believes in them. Their curiosity, enthusiasm, and passion for discovering new things inspire and enrich me every day.
column6: The positive atmosphere and strong sense of community in my classroom make teaching a joy.Their motivation and kindness make every day rewarding. I also find it very meaningful to provide my students with stability and structure, especially when they might not always have that in other parts of their lives.
column7: Every week is different and often unpredictable, as every child is an individual and things donâ€™t always go as planned.I do most of my detailed preparation during the school holidays, when I have the time to plan ahead thoroughly.During the week, I focus on short-term preparations, grading and adjusting or creating teaching materials based on the needs that arise in class. :)
column11: I sometimes use AI tools like ChatGPT for lesson preparation, especially to get a rough structure or initial ideas for a topic. That usually works very well. However, for detailed planning, itâ€™s often not helpful because the tool lacks access to my specific teaching materials and sometimes itâ€™s easy to get lost in too many ideas. I also enjoy using it for writing emails or parent letters, as well as for creating exercises such as true-or-false questions or solution keys.Itâ€™s also very helpful for differentiating learning materials, for example by simplifying texts or adapting tasks for students who need more support.
column12: In one lesson, my students struggled more than expected with a science experiment because they focused mainly on the results instead of the process of observing and reasoning. I realized they needed more guidance in formulating hypotheses and interpreting what they saw. I adjusted by slowing down the pace, modeling the thought process step by step, and using guiding questions to help them connect their observations to scientific concepts.
column13: Preparing for assessment;In the daily organization and structuring of tasks.
column16: I differentiate my teaching by offering tasks at different levels of difficulty and by providing additional support or challenges depending on the studentsâ€™ needs.
column17: Administrative tasks;Communication with parents;Helping struggling students;To divide myself among 26 children (number of students).
column20: It depends on the subject and the specific learning goals. I monitor progress through individual learning objectives, learning assessments, and tools such as research journals and learning coaching conversations.These methods help me understand each studentâ€™s development and support them according to their needs.
column22: What excites me most about AIâ€™s potential in education is its ability to make learning more personalized and efficient. AI can help adapt materials to different learning levels, support teachers with time-consuming tasks like creating exercises or giving feedback and offer students instant, tailored support. I also see great potential in using AI to spark creativity and curiosity.
column24: I would delegate time-consuming administrative and organizational tasks, such as preparing lesson materials, grading assignments and writing reports or parent letters. I would also use it to create differentiated exercises and visual learning aids for different ability levels, so I could focus more on supporting my students personally and spending quality time with them in the classroom.
column26: If a new AI tutor were added to my digital environment, it would need to integrate smoothly with my existing tools, teaching-style and materials. A key feature should be reliable correction support: for example, checking spelling, grammar, and content accuracy in student work, while still recognizing individual phrasing and creativity. It should also help me provide personalized feedback efficiently.
column27: Gives quick, useful results;Customizable for my classes;Reliable and accurate
column29: I believe in it!!!! :) Please do it
column30: It should help the student by providing structure and showing clear next steps. It should recognize mistakes, explain them in a simple way, and help strengthen the basic concepts needed to understand the topic. Most importantly, it should guide the student so they know what to do and can work more confidently and independently.
column31: it would be to ensure they are better protected from the dangers of digital media. Children should be able to explore and learn online safely, without being exposed to harmful content or unhealthy influences.
column32: Student monitoring would be essential. The AI should help me identify each childâ€™s learning progress and needs. It should also support me in giving meaningful feedback and clearly showing each studentâ€™s current learning level.
column33: Better student results;More engagement;Improved independence;Reduced teacher workload
column34: Go and make a tool! :) xoxo

column3: History, Philosophy, Literature, Ethics, Religion - Grade 7
column5: I enjoy the process of helping young people learn how to be more curious about life, our human world, and most importantly, themselves.
column6: The student's curiosity once we get started with a topic.
column7: I typically try to spend as much time as possible with the students in the classroom because this is where the magic is. I do of course have preparation time, but I find that with LLMs this can be done much quicker than in the past. I find that I need a few hours on Friday afternoon to prepare for the following week because of the ongoing conversation I have with the LLM. It's much more efficient and productive. For feedback I meet with each student one to one for 20 - 30 minutes each week to get a feeling for how they are absorbing the content of lessons and to see if they need support making progress with their projects.
column9: Various internet sites for research opportunities. I use Youtube a lot when I find engaging videos. I would like to use LLMs more often but want to first learn about how to best use them with the students in a healthy and productive way.
column11: As I mentioned above in Question 2.1, I use AI all the time to plan my lessons. I enter in curriculum goals, the subject or content I'd like to explore, and my favorite ideas, books, teachers, and lessons from my own learning. I then have a conversation with the LLM to get ideas for activities or resources to most efficiently plan my lesson. Each week we discuss the progress we are making as a group, the challenges faced in the lessons, and add new ideas that come up over the week per the student's interests and curiosity. I then have a discussion with the LLM to move forward into the next week as fluidly as possible.
column12: I was trying to teach students about the progression of life on earth and realized they were struggling with the large gaps in time between evolutionary progress and change. I adjusted my approach by going into our long activity room and created a to scale timeline of life on earth so they could better grasp how long change can sometimes take, but then once the change happens it gets faster and faster.
column13: Understanding new topics;Applying knowledge;Staying motivated;Managing time;Preparing for assessment
column14: Behavioral signs;Performance on work;Class participation;Student communication
column16: We are a project based school so this is managed while helping students set goals and make progress on their individual projects.
column18: If students learn how to engage in a healthy way with LLMs it could certainly help with this. If they had their own bot tailored to their needs it would be great.
column20: Given that my subject areas are the humanities my main tracking tool is conversation. If they are able to have a discussion about the topic it is a good sign they are grasping the content. I also have them write about their process of insight and understanding and this writing is also a good way for me to track progress.
column22: I have already seen the benefits in terms of planning lessons and I am very excited about this going forward. I am also excited how LLMs will support students individually, but I do feel that the students need to learn about how to use this technology properly and in a healthy way. In themselves these tools can be as damaging as they can be helpful, and it is important that we keep this in mind as we bring it into the classroom.
column23: Student overreliance;Accuracy or misinformation;Data privacy;Accessibility;Academic integrity
column24: Planning of curriculum and lessons for sure. I think there would also be a place to track student progress in a more nuanced way over time. The big trust barrier would be to create individual student learning guide bots.
column26: We would need to have the correct allowances for student use. It would be difficult to allow students unfettered use of the technology without more experience, digital literacy, and digital wellbeing training.
column27: Easy to learn and use;Integrates with existing systems;Gives quick, useful results;Customizable for my classes;Reliable and accurate
column29: I think it is a great tool and will be a massive benefit for everyone who learns how to use it. It also has the chance of being a disaster, like most powerful technologies, so proper awareness and implementation are crucial.
column30: Encouragement and feedback to their questions or points of struggle.
column31: I would love a bit more interaction. Just getting info off the screen or copying - pasting is not learning. But an interactive approach bringing in language, visual learning, etc, would be a great addition.
column32: I think the conversation focus would be most helpful. If there is a dialogue there will be tremendous amounts of data that the AI can collect and use in the future to help the students.
column33: Better student results;More engagement;Stronger confidence;Improved independence
column34: As with all powerful tech AI and LLMs have both tremendous potential to do good and cause harm. I am excited about using this technology more and more in the years to come, but I am also a proponent of a gradual and cautious approach. More is not necessarily always better. But more of the right things absolutely IS better.
